## 4. Well positioned to capitalize on the growing power sector

India's power sector lies at the intersection of demographic expansion, urbanisation, industrial growth, and energy transition. The combination of a large and growing population, rising urban concentration, increased electrification of consumption, and ambitious renewable energy goals will continue to drive significant investments in generation capacity, transmission infrastructure, and grid modernisation over the coming decades. (Source: CRISIL Report)

Accordingly to the CRISIL Report, the global wires and cables market stood at USD 280 billion in 2024, growing with a CAGR of 4.8% from 2019 to 2024. The market is expected to grow at a CAGR of 7.5% to 8.5% from 2024 to 2029, reaching a value of USD 400 to USD 420 billion by 2029. (Source: CRISIL Report) In Fiscal 2025, the India's cables and wire market were valued at approximately ₹ 1,951 billion, up from ₹ 859 billion in Fiscal 2019, registering a CAGR of 14.6%. This notable surge can be primarily attributed to a remarkable growth of HV and EHV (above 33 KV cables) and elastomeric cables, which have registered exponential growth on the back of increased expansion of transmission lines and electrification initiatives in rural areas. The Indian wires and cables market size is expected to grow at a CAGR of 11% to 13% between Fiscal 2025 and Fiscal 2030 and to reach ₹ 3,350 billion to ₹ 3,550 billion by Fiscal 2030 due to ongoing infrastructure development projects, surge in construction activities and increasing digital connectivity. (Source: CRISIL Report)

The global conductors market stood at USD 36 billion in 2024, growing with a CAGR of 4.4% from 2019 to 2024. The market is expected to grow at a CAGR of 5.5% to 6.5% from 2024 to 2029, reaching a value of USD 47 billion to USD 49 billion by 2029.
